channel.title: Computer makes 1 long beep, doesn't start up
channel.description:
So today I decided to clean my computer's fan (above the heatsink). I took out the fan, brought it outside, and cleaned it with compressed air. I usually clean it with just a vacuum because I don't feel like taking out the fan, but I decided I should take out the fan today. When I finished cleaning the fan, I looked at all the shit over the heatsink. I took a vacuum (with a plastic top) and cleaned the heatsink with that. I didn't blow any compressed air into the heatsink. Then, I put the fan back over the heatsink and snapped everything into place, except I forgot to plug the fan back into the motherboard. I turned on the computer and I got 1 long beep and no visual, then unplugged the computer 2 seconds later. I plugged the fan into the motherboard then turned the computer back on. The long beep was still there. It does require a little bit of effort to put the fan back into place. I contacted Geek Squad about the issue and multiple people told me to bring it in because they can't see it, so I attached pictures. Why is my computer making a long beep? It's a Gateway DX4860-UB33P computer, the warranty expired, it has an Intel i5 processor. I took out the CMOS battery for 15 seconds because some website somewhere said that might help (and it didn't do anything). I haven't upgraded this computer at all, everything is stock. All the information can be found here: http://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=N82E16883113202
Pictures (click for full size):
[url=http://imageshack.us/a/img43/1672/z2ot.jpg][img width=600 height=400]http://imageshack.us/a/img43/1672/z2ot.jpg[/img][/url] [url=http://imageshack.us/a/img607/1926/xji4.jpg][img width=600 height=400]http://imageshack.us/a/img607/1926/xji4.jpg[/img][/url]

item.title: Computer makes 1 long beep, doesn't start up
item.dc:creator: @holylouis holylouis
item.description:
@holylouis wrote:

something isnt making good connection make sure all ur cables are in snugged

double check the ram bc sometimes they come loose when doing something to pc i had that happen and it took me 2 days to figure out wtf was up

Read full topic
item.source: Computer makes 1 long beep, doesn't start up

item.title: Computer makes 1 long beep, doesn't start up
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

That’s good. Keep in mind everything stated in this thread for next time you attempt to do this. (or anything else)
Computer parts are very fragile, be more careful next time.

Read full topic
item.source: Computer makes 1 long beep, doesn't start up

item.title: Computer makes 1 long beep, doesn't start up
item.dc:creator: @Fridder Fridder
item.description:
@Fridder wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:8, topic:536223”]Did you even look at POST beep codes? Without knowing which BIOS you have it’s difficult to determine the cause, a continuous beep could be a short circuit.

Also, you should never remove the heatsink and not replace the thermal compound, it loses the heat conductivity… check it isn’t overheating too.

Edit: only just read the post above, this sounds like overheating from past repairs that I’ve done.[/quote]

Yes, I looked at the POST beep codes. I didn’t remove the heatsink, I just stuck a vacuum in there and cleaned it. The computer is working now for whatever reason, I’m actually using it right now. Everything went back to normal when I removed the RAM, blew on it, and re-inserted it.

Is there a free hardware test I can run to make sure everything is working properly and the computer won’t take a shit?

Also my BIOS is American Megatrends Inc. P02-A1 (date 8/1/2011), I wasn’t able to get that information when I had no visual.

AtomicInt_:

you should have put a paperclip or something small through the blades in the fan so it doesn’t spin while you’re cleaning it.

I know, I held the fan with my fingers, didn’t let it spin, and cleaned each individual fan (I broke a fan last year D:)

Read full topic
item.source: Computer makes 1 long beep, doesn't start up

item.title: Computer makes 1 long beep, doesn't start up
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:10, topic:536223”][quote author=AtomicInt_ link=topic=655035.msg4386461#msg4386461 date=1385766528]
or you broke the bearings by making the fan spin too quickly
[/quote]
Unlikely… my fans comfortably run at 2400RPM, I doubt an air compressor will get up to those kinds of speeds.[/quote]

Depends on the air compressor, the one I own is a air compressor typically found in car shops with the big tank, I assumed he had the same because he had to take it outside. I also have a small air compressor that just plugs into my car which doesn’t spit out air that fast, regardless it is still a possibility. He didn’t include the specifics.

Read full topic
item.source: Computer makes 1 long beep, doesn't start up

item.title: Computer makes 1 long beep, doesn't start up
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

AtomicInt_:

or you broke the bearings by making the fan spin too quickly

Unlikely… my fans comfortably run at 2400RPM, I doubt an air compressor will get up to those kinds of speeds.

Read full topic
item.source: Computer makes 1 long beep, doesn't start up

item.title: Computer makes 1 long beep, doesn't start up
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

You shouldn’t ever use an air compressor to clean fans for a few reasons, if your air compressor doesn’t have a water trap as air goes through the hose the humidity of the air passing through tends to build up, so the parts could be wet or you broke the bearings by making the fan spin too quickly, you should have put a paperclip or something small through the blades in the fan so it doesn’t spin while you’re cleaning it.

Read full topic
item.source: Computer makes 1 long beep, doesn't start up

item.title: Computer makes 1 long beep, doesn't start up
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Did you even look at POST beep codes? Without knowing which BIOS you have it’s difficult to determine the cause, a continuous beep could be a short circuit.

Also, you should never remove the heatsink and not replace the thermal compound, it loses the heat conductivity… check it isn’t overheating too.

Edit: only just read the post above, this sounds like overheating from past repairs that I’ve done.

Read full topic
item.source: Computer makes 1 long beep, doesn't start up

item.title: Computer makes 1 long beep, doesn't start up
item.dc:creator: @Fridder Fridder
item.description:
@Fridder wrote:

[quote=“ixia, post:5, topic:536223”]Did you still wear that static wrist band thingy when touching the stuff inside? You might of broke it.
(i’m guessing)[/quote]

No I didn’t, I touched the side of the case while it was plugged in. I’ll buy some anti-static gloves and re-seat the RAM. I unplugged 1 of the sticks and pushed it back in very carefully, and now I get 2 beeps it turns on and works. When I turn on the computer, it spins all the fans and gets ready to turn on, then turns off, and turns back on again a few seconds later. I may bring it into a local repair shop just to be safe.

Read full topic

item.title: Computer makes 1 long beep, doesn't start up
item.dc:creator: @Fridder Fridder
item.description:
@Fridder wrote:

kickingjamie:

I’d double check everything is plugged into the motherboard properly. You might have dislodged something trying to get the fan out and back in (like you said it requires a bit of effort to get it back into place)

Like the RAM sticks? I double checked everything except for that. :s
